Message.Msg: Everyone has skillfully been herded into all the wrong places, not just in Amazon. I am honestly a little surprised that more haven't figured out the phase transition underway. But, cognitive biases are powerful and everyone is seeing the similarities with the past and not the differences... If there are any retail longs on this board, do yourself a favor and sell 25%-50% of your holdings. Lower capital gains tax now than later. It has to go up another 5% from here to offset the capital gains increase. More likely, this will drop 5-10% and you can reenter later (though I suspect by then the real economics will be clear and it will drop far more).

Topic.Title: After all is said and done . . .

Message.Msg: And what happens when institutional longs realize that allowing these trading games is the primary driver (yes, even when they "inflate" portfolios) of retail investor distrust and thus capital constantly leaving the market. What if institutional longs (who hold the majority of the stock and can without question change the game) decide to stop playing and allow the market to again service its primary purpose of capital allocation for productive investment? If they don't soon, it will be unrecoverable... Either way, I'll be here for the drop. This is a scam. Question for the longs: How much did it hurt Google to announce the 20% price cut in Google Cloud services? Now, how much does it hurt Amazon that it reduced prices by 25% in response? Separate question: Have any of the longs figured out how Benny #$%$ printing will alter the economics of Amazon's model? What about the relative economics? Geeg? Bruce? NAS? I mean all you guys are geniuses and tell us how stupid we are... Do tell what the future holds.

Topic.Title: Mr. Einhorn, Just Do It!

Message.Msg: A bunch of analysts just downgraded INTC on "margin hit" if it were to act as a foundry for AAPL. Never mind that it would be INCREMENTAL gross profit and simultaneously weaken volumes and production economics elsewhere -- but then again none of these analysts seem to understand competitive strategy at well. Of course, were Scamazon to do anything like this, they'd all raise the price target to $500... Here's the thing folks... When you are gaining leverage on (previously purchased) long lived fixed assets or filling capacity on underutilized production lines, then incremental gross profit is a good thing (particularly when it limits TSMC's potential gain). When you are investing new capital (Amazon's fulfillment centers), you need to see a significant incremental gross profit contribution else the real math doesn't work. No one ever answered my question. Once a customer is already at Amazon's website, does Amazon make more GROSS PROFIT if that customer buys Amazon or 3P? Seriously... I'm looking for the Wall Street wizards to give an intellectually honest and consistent response to the analysis of INTC acting as a foundry for AAPL versus AMZN 3P.... They won't be able to do it. The WS sell side analyst coverage of the two companies is either incompetent or intellectually dishonest...

Topic.Title: Mr. Einhorn, Just Do It!

Message.Msg: I'm being censored again, but I'm going to have an attorney try his hand at posting my content so we can get an official explanation from Yahoo as to why it censors content that adheres to the T&C's... In the interim, I'll simply say this. Analysts are remarkably intellectually inconsistent in their treatment of INTC and AMZN. INTC acting as a Fab for AAPL is viewed as "bad for margins" while amazon 3P is "good for margins". The economic reality is precisely the opposite if one understands the incremental costs to serve and thus opportunity cost of not having that business. INTC is utilizing existing fabs and keeping volumes away from TSMC, affecting its economics. Amazon is building new capacity to sell 3P items to customers it had already attracted to its website. Improper understanding of cost drivers and LT economics already killed much of our manufacturing base. You have WS analysts' fuzzy thinking to thank for it...

Topic.Title: Mr. Einhorn, Just Do It!

Message.Msg: When INTC gets enhanced leverage on its fiixed asset investment, analysts say it "will hurt margins" (because it actually makes money). When Amazon builds new low ROIC facilities to accomodate more 3P (which would have been sold via Amazon anyway since the customer came to the Amazon website), it "boosts margins". The new math... No one really understands cost drivers and competitive strategy anymore...
